G.L. c. 218, \u00a719 and \u00a721.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 218, §19 and §21 because the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a72.proposition: Venue is proper in the Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §2 because the Premises and events giving rise to this action occurred within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, §14, any landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises is liable for damages.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the premises caused by a landlord’s acts or omissions.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that a landlord breaches it where tenants are substantially deprived of the use and enjoyment of their premises due to conditions that are the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts, failures to act, or what the landlord permits. The court expressly rejects an intent requirement and emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct (including omissions where he has control) leading to substantial interference constitutes a breach, matching the proposition stated.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the premises caused by a landlord’s acts or omissions.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment and explains that it protects tenants from serious interference with their tenancy, including where the landlord’s conduct consists of omissions that allow unsanitary, flooding conditions to persist. The court links G.L. c. 186, § 14 to the common-law covenant and notes that liability arises when the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts or omissions is interference with the tenant’s rights, without requiring malicious intent. This aligns with the proposition that the covenant protects tenants from substantial interference caused by a landlord’s acts or omissions.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … [M]ore recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Defendant had a statutory and common-law duty to maintain the Premises in a habitable condition and to refrain from actions or inactions that substantially impair the character of the tenancy.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames the residential lease as a contract in which the landlord promises to “deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition,” and ties this duty both to the implied warranty of habitability (common law) and to statutory obligations under the State Sanitary Code. It further explains that the tenant’s rent obligation is interdependent with the landlord’s duty to maintain habitability and that the landlord may not avoid this duty by inaction, thereby recognizing a duty to refrain from conduct (or nonconduct) that materially impairs the tenancy’s habitability.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “[A] lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises. These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations. Thus, the tenant’s obligation to pay rent is predicated on the landlord’s obligation to deliver and maintain the premises in habitable condition.” … “In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes.”

Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 368 Mass. 425.proposition: Defendant had a statutory and common-law duty to maintain the Premises in a habitable condition and to refrain from actions or inactions that substantially impair the character of the tenancy.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: The presence of mold and inadequate ventilation constitute a condition rendering the Premises unsafe and unfit for human habitation within the meaning of G.L. c. 239, §8A, G.L. c. 111, §§127A–127L, and applicable sanitary codes (105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.).

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7127A\u2013127L.proposition: The presence of mold and inadequate ventilation constitute a condition rendering the Premises unsafe and unfit for human habitation within the meaning of G.L. c. 239, §8A, G.L. c. 111, §§127A–127L, and applicable sanitary codes (105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.).

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The presence of mold and inadequate ventilation constitute a condition rendering the Premises unsafe and unfit for human habitation within the meaning of G.L. c. 239, §8A, G.L. c. 111, §§127A–127L, and applicable sanitary codes (105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.).

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The substantial interference with Plaintiff’s health and safety constitutes a breach even absent an eviction or express act of harassment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court explicitly holds that a landlord’s serious interference with tenants’ use of their premises—here, the inability to safely use common areas due to drug activity—can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on the landlord’s omissions, without any eviction or express act of harassment. The opinion focuses on the severity of the interference with health and safety and the landlord’s failure to act, not on formal eviction or direct harassment, as the basis for potential liability.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”}

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The substantial interference with Plaintiff’s health and safety constitutes a breach even absent an eviction or express act of harassment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The case focuses on what level of landlord fault is required to establish a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, holding that at least negligent conduct with notice or reason to know of the condition is necessary; a mere statutory violation (here, strict-liability lead paint liability) is not enough. It does not address whether substantial interference with health and safety can constitute a breach in the absence of eviction or express harassment, and in fact the opinion is about the fault standard, not about the need for eviction or harassment. Thus it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Defendant’s conduct was willful or, at a minimum, negligent, and caused Plaintiff personal discomfort, property loss, and emotional distress.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly affirms findings that the landlord’s (defendant’s) conduct was at least negligent and, in key respects, intentional and outrageous, and that it caused the tenant (plaintiff on counterclaims) emotional distress, as well as loss relating to the condition and value of the apartment. The court upholds liability for negligent failure to maintain, breach of warranty of habitability, violation of quiet enjoyment, and intentional infliction of emotional distress, all tied to the tenant’s personal discomfort and property-related loss.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “On the emotional distress counterclaim, the judge determined that Gonzalez had proved that Haddad's intentional and outrageous conduct had caused her to suffer severe emotional distress… On the warranty of habitability counterclaim, the judge reasoned that Gonzalez was entitled to the difference between the actual value of the apartment in its defective condition and the fair market value of the apartment… Haddad offered to rent Gonzalez an apartment that was essentially uninhabitable… Gonzalez's requests for repairs were largely ignored… the judge was justified in concluding that Gonzalez had made out a common law case of intentional infliction of emotional distress.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was willful or, at a minimum, negligent, and caused Plaintiff personal discomfort, property loss, and emotional distress.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case holds that liability under the quiet enjoyment statute does not depend on the landlord’s intent or willfulness and that financial inability is not a defense; it focuses on whether the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct was deprivation of heat. It does not characterize the landlords’ conduct as willful or negligent, nor does it discuss personal discomfort, property loss, or emotional distress as specific elements of damages. Thus the opinion does not support the broader proposition that defendant’s conduct was willful or negligent and caused those specific harms.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’ … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to … an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7127L.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain habitability and to comply with the State Sanitary Code also constitutes an unfair interference within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, §14 and G.L. c. 111, §127L.

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain habitability and to comply with the State Sanitary Code also constitutes an unfair interference within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, §14 and G.L. c. 111, §127L.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses State Sanitary Code violations and a breach of the warranty of habitability, but it does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 186, §14 or G.L. c. 111, §127L, nor does it characterize the habitability or code violations as an “unfair interference” under those statutes. The sections on habitability and the code focus on rent abatement and regulatory requirements, not on statutory interference-with-tenancy remedies. Therefore, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs. … Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability…”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain habitability and to comply with the State Sanitary Code also constitutes an unfair interference within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, §14 and G.L. c. 111, §127L.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Hemingway is a concurrence/dissent focused on implied warranty of habitability, the effect of State Sanitary Code violations on rent obligations, and the interaction with G.L. c. 239, §8A. It does not interpret or even mention G.L. c. 186, §14 or c. 111, §127L, nor does it characterize Sanitary Code violations or failures to maintain habitability as an “unfair interference” within the meaning of those statutes. Accordingly, this opinion does not provide authority for the specific statutory proposition claimed.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The present situation in this Commonwealth is not one of a void in the law with reference to what is required of dwelling units to constitute ‘fitness for human habitation’ (G. L. c. 111, § 127A). As already noted in this opinion, we have had considerable legislative and administrative attention and action on this subject. We have the numerous statutes passed by the Legislature. … It remains for the courts only to accommodate their rules of common law to enable tenants to enforce against landlords these mandatory, detailed, precise and easily understandable minimum standards of fitness of dwelling units for human occupation…”
